content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Ethan Schmehl: Well, I was born in Chicago, just a few blocks away from where I live now, actually. Growing up in the East North Central region, I remember the neighborhood was pretty tight-knit, though not without its challenges. My parents were both working hard to make ends meet, and while they didn't have a lot of money, they always made sure I had the basics and a good education. My father had a graduate degree in engineering, and my mother has a bachelor's in education. She worked part-time as a teacher's aide, which I think helped her stay connected to the school system. I was raised in a Catholic household, and even though I wasn't super religious as a kid, I still found comfort in the traditions and community events we attended. I went to public school, and while my family's income was below average, both of my parents pushed me to do well in school. I ended up getting a bachelor's degree in social work, which I always felt was a way to give back to the community. I got married in my early 30s, and I've been working full-time as a case manager at a local nonprofit ever since. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always tried to stay positive and focused on helping others.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Ethan Schmehl: There was definitely a crossroads moment for me, and it came right after I graduated from college. I had been working part-time while I was in school, mostly at a community center that served low-income families. I remember one particular day, I was helping a single mother and her two kids who were struggling with food insecurity. I saw how exhausted she was, how she was trying her best but just barely keeping her head above water. That experience really hit me hard, and I realized I wanted to dedicate my career to helping people like her. I had a job offer from a corporate firm that paid well, but it was in a different field—finance. I almost took it because the money was tempting, especially with my family's financial background. But I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being pulled in the wrong direction. I talked it over with my wife-to-be, who was also working in a nonprofit, and she encouraged me to follow my heart. In the end, I chose the social work path, and I've never regretted it. That decision shaped who I am today—someone who values community, service, and making a difference, even if it doesn't always come with a big paycheck.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Ethan Schmehl: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like a weight on my chest for weeks, going back and forth between the security of the corporate job and the purpose I felt in social work. I remember sitting at my parents' kitchen table one night, staring at the job offer letter, and just feeling like something inside me was screaming, 'This isn't who you are.' I knew I wanted to be someone who stood up for people who couldn't stand up for themselves. It wasn't just about money—it was about meaning. I didn't want to look back years from now and wonder what might have been, but I also didn't want to live a life that didn't align with my values. In the end, I chose the path that felt true to who I was, even if it meant fewer luxuries and more long hours. I think that decision was the moment I truly became the person I am today.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Ethan Schmehl: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during that time would have made a huge difference. My wife was definitely that person for me—she didn't push me toward either choice, but she listened and reminded me of what really mattered to me. I also think a mentor in the social work field could have helped me see the long-term impact of my decision. At the time, I was pretty young and still figuring out who I wanted to be, so having someone with more experience to guide me would have given me more confidence. I remember talking to a professor from my undergrad who had worked in nonprofit organizations, and he shared some of his own struggles with choosing purpose over paycheck. That conversation stuck with me, and it reinforced the idea that I didn't have to choose the easiest path to be successful. In the end, I think it was a combination of my own values, the support from my wife, and a few key people who believed in what I wanted to do that helped me make the right choice.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Ethan Schmehl: Yes, I'm married to my wife, Claire, and we have two children—a daughter named Lily, who's six, and a son, Max, who's four. Claire and I met in college, actually, during a group project for a sociology class. She was studying public health, and I was in social work, so we had a lot in common in terms of our interests and values. We got married right after I graduated, and we've been through a lot together—raising kids, managing the financial challenges of working in the nonprofit sector, and just trying to make sure our kids grow up in a stable, loving environment. Claire works part-time as a community health coordinator, which allows her to be more present for the kids, and I handle the full-time case manager role. It's not always easy, but we've built a life that's meaningful to both of us. Our kids are pretty active, and we try to make sure they understand the importance of helping others, even at a young age. We volunteer at a local food pantry on weekends, and I think that's something that's already shaping their worldview.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and experiences I've had. From my childhood in Chicago to the pivotal decision I made after college, every step has led me to where I am today—with my family, working in social work, and striving to make a difference in my community. It's interesting to look back and see how the values instilled in me by my parents, the support from my wife, and the moments of clarity during tough decisions all contributed to who I've become. I'm grateful for the path I chose, even if it wasn't the easiest one, because it's the one that aligns with my sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Ethan Schmehl: My immediate family includes my parents, both of whom have been incredibly supportive throughout my life. My father, Hans, is a civil engineer, and he's always had a strong work ethic. Even though he's retired now, he still volunteers with local infrastructure projects, which I think is a great way for him to stay connected to his community. My mother, Maria, is a former teacher's aide and has always been passionate about education. She's the one who encouraged me to pursue higher education, even when we were struggling financially. Our relationship has always been close, and even though we don't see each other as often as I'd like due to my job, I know I can always count on them for advice and support. My sister, Anna, lives in Milwaukee and works as a nurse. We talk regularly, and she's been a huge source of encouragement for me, especially as a parent. She's the one who always reminds me that it's okay to ask for help, and that's something I try to pass on to my kids as well.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Ethan Schmehl: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Marcus, a fellow case manager at the nonprofit I work for. We've been friends for almost a decade now, and he's been through a lot with me—whether it's late-night shifts, tough cases, or just trying to balance work and family life. He's one of the few people I can really be myself around, and he's always had my back. Then there's my mentor, Linda, who started out in social work just like I did. She's been a huge influence on me, not just professionally but personally. She taught me the importance of patience, empathy, and resilience. I still reach out to her when I'm struggling with a tough situation or just need someone to talk to. And of course, there are the people I work with at the food pantry on weekends—some of them are volunteers, others are clients. I've formed some really meaningful connections with them, and I think those relationships have helped me stay grounded in why I do what I do. It's not just about the work; it's about the people and the impact we can have on each other's lives.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Ethan Schmehl: I live in a neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's a mix of old and new—some of the older buildings have been around for decades, while there are also newer developments popping up. The area has a strong sense of community, and I really appreciate that. There are a lot of families here, like me, trying to make ends meet but still finding ways to support each other. The local park is a big part of our neighborhood life; it's where we have block parties, where the kids play, and where I sometimes take my kids to read or just sit and watch the world go by. There's also a community center nearby that offers free programs for kids and adults, which I think is really important for people who might not have access to other resources. I've seen a lot of changes in the area over the years—some for the better, some not so much—but I still feel connected to this place. It's where I started, and it's where I want my kids to grow up, even if it's not perfect. There's a lot of resilience here, and I think that's something I want my children to learn from.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Ethan Schmehl: I would say I feel pretty safe here, though I know it's not the kind of safety that comes without effort. There are definitely parts of the neighborhood where you have to be cautious, especially at night, but overall, I think the sense of community helps keep things in check. People look out for each other, and there's a kind of unspoken understanding that we're all in this together. I've seen neighbors help each other during tough times—whether it's fixing a broken fence, watching out for kids while someone's at work, or just offering a friendly word when things feel heavy. That kind of support makes me feel secure, even if the area isn't without its challenges. I think safety is more about the relationships you build than the physical environment alone, and I'm grateful for the people who make this place feel like home.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Ethan Schmehl: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, there's a real sense of community that I think is rare in bigger cities. People know each other, they look out for each other, and there's a shared understanding that life isn't always easy, but we can support one another through it. I love that my kids can ride their bikes around the block without me constantly worrying about traffic or strangers. The local park is a big part of our routine, and it's amazing to see how many families use it—some for sports, others just to sit and chat. But of course, there are challenges too. The cost of living here has gone up, and even with both of us working, it's tight sometimes. There are also issues with crime in certain parts of the neighborhood, which is something I try to shield my kids from as much as possible. Still, I believe in this place. It's where I grew up, where I found my purpose, and where I want my kids to grow up too. I think the key is staying involved, staying connected, and not letting the struggles define the whole experience. There's beauty in the resilience of this community, and I'm proud to be a part of it.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about my wife, Claire, and our kids made me realize how much we've built together—not just as a family, but as a team working toward a shared purpose. It's not always easy, especially with the financial challenges of working in the nonprofit sector, but knowing that we're raising our children with values like empathy and service gives me strength. When I spoke about my parents and sister, I was reminded of how their support and sacrifices have been a foundation for everything I've achieved. And when I described my neighborhood, I felt a renewed sense of pride in the community I call home. Even with its challenges, it's a place of resilience, connection, and belonging. It's comforting to know that the people around me—family, friends, neighbors—are the ones who truly define the life I live.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Ethan Schmehl: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though there are definitely some variations depending on the cases I'm handling at work. I start my week early most mornings, usually around 6:30 a.m., since I need to get the kids up, get them ready for school, and get myself to work by 8. My job as a case manager is pretty demanding—some days I'm meeting with clients, others I'm coordinating with other agencies or attending meetings. Mondays are usually the busiest because that's when we review the week's caseload and plan out our priorities. I work from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., though I often stay late a few times a week, especially if there's something urgent that needs attention. On the weekends, I try to balance work with family time. We usually go to the park, do some errands, or have a quiet evening at home. Claire and I also volunteer at the food pantry on Saturdays, which is something we both look forward to—it's a chance to give back and connect with the community in a different way. The kids have soccer practice on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and we make sure to have dinner together most nights, even if it's just a simple meal. It's not always perfect, but I think the rhythm of the week helps us stay grounded and focused on what really matters.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Ethan Schmehl: I work as a case manager at a local nonprofit organization called 'HopeBridge,' which focuses on providing support services to low-income families, individuals experiencing homelessness, and those in crisis situations. My job involves coordinating with other agencies, assessing clients' needs, and helping them access resources like housing, food assistance, and mental health services. I work full-time, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., though I often stay late a few times a week, especially when there are urgent cases or meetings that need to be handled. The work can be emotionally draining at times, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I've had clients who have gone from being homeless to finding stable housing, or who have been able to get back on their feet after a difficult period. Those moments remind me why I chose this path. It's not always glamorous, and the pay isn't great, but I know I'm making a difference in people's lives, and that's what matters most to me.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Ethan Schmehl: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I try to get in a run or a walk most mornings before the kids are up, even if it's just around the block. It's my way of clearing my mind and starting the day with some focus. I also make it a point to read every night, usually a book on social justice or personal development. It's something I started doing after college, and it's become a way for me to reflect on my own values and the work I do. I also have a small garden in the backyard where I grow herbs and a few vegetables. It's not much, but it's something I can do with the kids, and it gives me a sense of accomplishment. I think these little things—whether it's the garden, the reading, or the exercise—help me stay grounded and remind me that even in a busy life, there's still room for small joys and personal growth.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Ethan Schmehl: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing short meditation sessions while the kids are still asleep, just a few minutes of deep breathing and grounding exercises. It's something I read about in a book on resilience, and I found it really helped me manage the stress that comes with my job. I also began setting aside time each evening to journal about my day—what went well, what challenged me, and how I felt about the work I did. It's been a small but meaningful shift, helping me process everything more clearly. Another thing is that I've started taking my kids to a local community garden on weekends, which has been a nice way to spend time together and teach them about sustainability and where food comes from. It's been a good reminder that even in the midst of a busy life, there are still opportunities to grow, both literally and figuratively.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Ethan Schmehl: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts pretty early. Lily, my daughter, gets up around 6:45 a.m., and Max, my son, usually follows a few minutes later. They have a morning routine that includes brushing their teeth, getting dressed, and having breakfast together. Claire and I try to have a family breakfast most mornings, even if it's just toast and juice—it's a small way to start the day together. After breakfast, they get ready for school, and we head out by 7:30 a.m. to make sure they're at the bus stop on time. Lily is in first grade, and Max is in pre-K, so their school days are pretty different. Lily has a full day of classes, while Max is only there for a few hours. After school, Lily usually has soccer practice on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and she also participates in a weekly art club. Max has a playgroup on Mondays and Fridays, which is more about socialization than structured learning. On the days when they don't have activities, we try to do something educational or fun at home—like reading, playing board games, or going to the library. In the evenings, we have dinner together, and then it's usually storytime or some quiet time before bed. It's not always perfect, but I think the consistency of their routine helps them feel secure and grounded, which is especially important for Max since he's still so young. I also try to make sure they understand that even though their days are busy, they're always part of a bigger story—one where they're learning, growing, and being supported by the people around them.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about my wife, Claire, and our kids made me realize how much we've built together—not just as a family, but as a team working toward a shared purpose. It's not always easy, especially with the financial challenges of working in the nonprofit sector, but knowing that we're raising our children with values like empathy and service gives me strength. When I spoke about my parents and sister, I was reminded of how their support and sacrifices have been a foundation for everything I've achieved. And when I described my neighborhood, I felt a renewed sense of pride in the community I call home. Even with its challenges, it's a place of resilience, connection, and belonging. It's comforting to know that the people around me—family, friends, neighbors—are the ones who truly define the life I live.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Ethan Schmehl: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. I used to be pretty active as a kid, playing soccer and basketball with friends, but as I got older and started working full-time, I found it harder to keep up with that kind of routine. I do have a few health issues I've had to manage—mainly chronic lower back pain from years of sitting at a desk and lifting clients during home visits. I see a chiropractor every few months, and I've also started doing some physical therapy exercises at home to help with the stiffness. I also have high blood pressure, which I keep under control with a combination of diet, exercise, and medication. I try to eat as healthy as I can, though it's not always easy with the budget we have. We mostly stick to whole foods, cook at home, and limit processed snacks. I also make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always consistent. I think the biggest thing is that I've learned to listen to my body and not ignore the signs when something's off. It's not perfect, but I'm doing my best to take care of myself so I can keep doing the work I love and being there for my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Ethan Schmehl: For me, staying healthy is both easier and harder depending on the day. On the easier side, I find that having a routine helps a lot—like my morning runs or even just taking a walk with the kids. It gives me a sense of control and a moment to breathe before the chaos of the day starts. Also, knowing that my health directly affects my ability to be there for my family is a strong motivator. But on the harder side, it's the financial strain that makes it tough. Sometimes, even with the best intentions, we have to choose between buying healthy groceries or covering other essential expenses. I also struggle with consistency—there are days when I'm so busy or stressed that I skip meals or forget to take my medication. It's a constant balancing act, but I remind myself that small, consistent efforts matter more than perfection. I think the key is not to be too hard on myself when I slip up, but to keep moving forward, even if it's just one step at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Ethan Schmehl: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that have been pretty significant. The most notable was a flare-up of my chronic lower back pain, which got so bad that I had to take a few days off work and see a specialist. The doctor diagnosed me with a herniated disc, which explained the sharp pain I've been dealing with for years. It was a bit of a wake-up call, honestly. I started seeing a physical therapist more regularly and made a point to incorporate more stretching and strengthening exercises into my routine. It's been a slow process, but I've noticed some improvement. I also had a minor surgery last year to address the disc issue, and while it was scary, it's helped me manage the pain much better. On top of that, my blood pressure has been a bit more unstable lately, probably due to the stress of work and family life. I've had to be more diligent with my medication and diet, which hasn't always been easy, but I'm trying my best. It's been a tough couple of years, but I'm learning that taking care of my health is just as important as the work I do for others.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Ethan Schmehl: Honestly, there have been moments when my health issues did make things more difficult, especially with the demands of my job and being a parent. There were a few weeks after my surgery when I was on pain medication and couldn't keep up with the long hours or the physical demands of visiting clients. I had to rely more on Claire to help with the kids and the household, which was humbling but also a reminder of how important it is to ask for help when you need it. I remember one day when I was struggling to get out of bed, and I just sat there thinking about how I used to be so sure I could handle everything on my own. It was a hard lesson, but it taught me that taking care of myself isn't a weakness—it's a responsibility, especially when I have people depending on me. I've had to adjust my work schedule a bit, like taking shorter walks or doing more desk-based tasks when I'm not feeling up to it. It's not ideal, but I've found ways to adapt, and I'm grateful that my team at work has been understanding. The most important thing is that I'm still here for my kids, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Ethan Schmehl: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, there's been a lot of growth—both personally and professionally. I've been able to take more time to focus on my health, which has been a real blessing. I've also seen some of the clients I've worked with make real progress, which is incredibly rewarding. But there have also been moments of frustration and exhaustion. The cost of living has gone up again, and even with both of us working, it's been harder to make ends meet. I've had to make some tough choices about what we can and can't afford, which isn't easy when you're trying to raise kids and keep a roof over your head. I also feel like I'm constantly walking a tightrope between being present for my family and being there for the people I serve. Some days, I feel like I'm doing okay, and other days, I feel like I'm just barely holding it all together. But I keep reminding myself that we're all in this together—my family, my clients, my neighbors. And even on the hardest days, I try to find a way to show up, even if it's just in small ways.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes in routine and health made me reflect on how much my life has evolved over the past few years. It's amazing how something as simple as starting a morning meditation or journaling in the evening can make such a difference in how I handle the stress of my job and family life. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but now I see that taking small steps—like prioritizing my health or finding moments of mindfulness—can have a big impact. It's also been humbling to acknowledge the challenges I've faced with my back and blood pressure, and how they've affected my ability to keep up with the demands of work and being a parent. I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from my wife, my team at work, or even just from myself by setting realistic expectations. These changes, though small, have helped me feel more grounded and in control of my life, even when things don't always go as planned.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Ethan Schmehl: I think I've definitely struggled with anxiety, especially in the last year. It's not something I used to talk about much, but I've come to realize that it's a part of my life that I can't ignore. There are days when the weight of everything—work, family, the financial strain—it all just feels too much. I used to try to push through it, thinking that if I just kept going, it would pass. But I've learned that ignoring it doesn't make it go away. I've started seeing a therapist, which has been really helpful. It's not always easy to open up, especially with the stigma that still surrounds mental health, but I've found that talking through my feelings has made a big difference. I also try to practice self-compassion now, reminding myself that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. I don't want my kids to grow up thinking that being strong means never showing weakness, so I'm trying to model the idea that it's okay to ask for help, to take a break, or to just sit with your feelings for a while. It's a work in progress, but I'm grateful for the support I've received and the small steps I've taken toward better mental health.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Ethan Schmehl: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and moments of connection. Claire has been incredible, really stepping up in ways I didn't always expect. She's taken on more of the household responsibilities, especially when I was recovering from surgery or dealing with the back pain, and she's been my rock through all of it. The kids have been resilient too—Lily has started to understand the importance of helping others, and she's even started bringing her lunch to the food pantry to share with the kids there. Max is still too young to grasp everything, but he's learning to be kind and curious about the world around him. There have been tough moments, like when we had to cut back on some of our activities or when I was too tired to be fully present, but there's also been a lot of love and support. I think the biggest thing is that we're all learning to be more open about our struggles, whether it's with each other or with the people we serve. It's not perfect, but I feel like we're growing together, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Ethan Schmehl: I would say that religion has played a meaningful role in my life, especially growing up in a Catholic household. My parents always emphasized the importance of faith, not just as a set of beliefs but as a way of living—through acts of kindness, compassion, and service to others. Even though I didn't always attend church regularly as a kid, the values instilled in me through religious teachings have stayed with me. I still find comfort in the rituals, like attending Mass on Sundays or celebrating holidays with my family, and I believe that spirituality helps me stay grounded, especially during tough times. It's not about being perfect or following every rule, but more about the sense of community and the reminder that I'm part of something bigger than myself. I think that's why I'm drawn to social work—it feels like a natural extension of the values I was raised with. That said, I'm not rigid about it. I respect other beliefs and think that what matters most is how we treat each other, regardless of our faith.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Ethan Schmehl: To be honest, I don't use social media much these days. It's not that I dislike it, but I've found that it can be more of a distraction than a connection for me. I used to follow some local community pages and a few social justice advocates, but over time, I realized I was spending more time scrolling than actually engaging. I think part of it is that my work and family life already keep me pretty busy, and I want to make sure the time I have is spent meaningfully. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially those who live far away like my sister in Milwaukee. I also follow a few local nonprofits that do similar work to what I do, just to stay informed about what's happening in the community. But overall, I prefer face-to-face interactions or even a phone call over social media. There's something about the immediacy of a real conversation that just feels more genuine to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Ethan Schmehl: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's always been more about the people I know in real life—my wife, my family, my friends at work, and the community I'm part of. When things get overwhelming, I find that talking to someone face-to-face or even over the phone feels more genuine and comforting. That said, I can see how for some people, especially those who might not have a strong support network, social media could be a way to connect with others who are going through similar struggles. I just haven't found that need in myself, but I respect that it works for others. I think the key is knowing what kind of support you need and finding the right way to get it, whether it's online or in person.

Going through the questions about my health and recent challenges has made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything on my own, but now I see that taking care of myself—both physically and mentally—is just as important as the work I do for others. It's been hard to admit that I've struggled with anxiety and that my body has let me down in some ways, but I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help and to take things one step at a time. I'm grateful for the support from my wife, my family, and even my coworkers, who have been understanding when I've needed to slow down or adjust my schedule. It's not always easy, but I'm starting to feel more in control of my life, even when things don't go as planned. I hope that by being open about my struggles, I can show my kids that it's okay to be vulnerable and that taking care of yourself is a strength, not a weakness.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Ethan Schmehl: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, especially with the ongoing challenges at work and the financial pressures we've faced as a family. I used to think that stress was something I could just power through, but I've come to realize that it's not sustainable. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my daily routine, like those short meditation sessions I mentioned earlier, and it's made a noticeable difference. I also try to journal more often, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed—it helps me process my thoughts and not let them build up. Another thing that's helped is setting small, achievable goals for myself, whether it's getting a full night's sleep or taking a walk with the kids. I've also learned to be more open with Claire about how I'm feeling, which has strengthened our connection and made it easier to support each other. It's not like I've completely mastered stress management, but I feel like I'm developing healthier ways to cope, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Ethan Schmehl: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and car payments. We live in a two-bedroom apartment, and while it's not the most expensive place in the neighborhood, it's still a chunk of our budget—about $1,200 a month. Groceries are another big one, especially since we try to eat healthy and cook at home as much as possible. With two kids, it's not always easy to stretch the budget, but we've gotten pretty good at meal planning and buying in bulk when we can. Car payments are also a significant expense—Claire and I both need our cars for work, and we're still paying off the loans. We also have some insurance costs, including health insurance for the family, which is another fixed expense. On top of that, there are the occasional unexpected costs, like fixing a broken appliance or replacing a tire. It's a tight balance, but we've learned to prioritize what's essential and cut back on things we can live without. I think the hardest part is knowing that even with both of us working, we're always just a few missed paychecks away from needing to make some tough choices. But we're managing, and we're grateful for the support from our community and the people who believe in what we're doing.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Ethan Schmehl: Our household spent around $3,200 last month, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. The majority of that goes to rent, groceries, and car payments, as I mentioned earlier. We also have about $400 set aside for utilities—electricity, water, and internet—which can fluctuate depending on the season. Childcare is another big expense, especially since Claire works part-time and we need someone to watch the kids when we're both at work or volunteering. We've been trying to keep that cost down by using a local co-op for shared childcare, which has been a bit more affordable than traditional daycare. We also have a small amount allocated for personal expenses, like clothing, school supplies, and occasional outings. It's not a lot, but we've learned to be really careful with our money and prioritize what's most important. I think the biggest thing is that we're always looking for ways to stretch our budget without sacrificing the basics, and we're pretty good at finding community resources or discounts when we can.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Ethan Schmehl: We rent our home, actually. It's a two-bedroom apartment in a building that's been around for a while, and while it's not brand new, it's been pretty reliable. Rent is one of our biggest fixed costs, as I mentioned earlier, and it's something we've had to be really careful with. We chose to rent instead of buy because of the financial uncertainty that comes with being in the nonprofit sector—there are times when my hours can be unpredictable, and I didn't want to take on the burden of a mortgage. Plus, with the way the neighborhood has been changing, I thought it might be better to stay flexible. We've been in this apartment for about three years now, and while it's not perfect, it's a place that feels like home. It's also close to the park where the kids play, and we're within walking distance of the community center and the food pantry, which makes it easier to stay connected to the people and resources we rely on.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Ethan Schmehl: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the timing of certain expenses. For example, our utility bills tend to go up in the winter when we're using more heat, and they drop a bit in the summer. We also had a spike in our grocery costs around the holidays, especially when we were buying gifts for the kids and trying to make sure we had enough food for everyone during the busy holiday season. School-related expenses also come into play—like back-to-school supplies, uniforms, and activities. We usually budget a little extra for those times, but it still catches us off guard sometimes. Another thing that affected our budget was the cost of childcare—when Claire had to take on more hours at work to cover some unexpected expenses, we had to pay for additional childcare, which added a few hundred dollars a month. It's been a learning experience, really. We've had to get more creative with our budgeting, like using community programs for school supplies or relying on friends and family for help with gifts. It's not always easy, but I think we're getting better at anticipating these fluctuations and planning for them in advance.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown through the challenges we've faced together. It's been tough at times—whether it's dealing with my health issues, the financial strain, or the emotional weight of my work—but I've come to realize that vulnerability isn't a weakness. Talking about my struggles with anxiety and my health has helped me feel more connected to my family, and I've seen how Claire has stepped up in ways I didn't expect. I also think about how my kids are learning from all of this, even if they don't fully understand it yet. They see us being honest about our feelings, about asking for help, and about finding small ways to cope. It's not perfect, but I'm grateful for the support we've received from each other and from the people in our community. I hope that by being open about these things, I'm showing them that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, to take a break, and to seek help when you need it. Life isn't always easy, but it's the love, connection, and resilience we build together that make it worth it.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Ethan Schmehl: I would say we do save, but it's more of a cautious, small-scale approach rather than having a large emergency fund. We have a small savings account that we try to contribute to every month, even if it's just a few dollars. It's not much, but it gives us a sense of security in case something unexpected comes up. I think the biggest challenge is that we're always trying to balance saving with the immediate needs of the family—like groceries, rent, and the kids' activities. We've learned to set aside whatever we can after paying the bills, and sometimes that means saving less during certain months. I also try to take advantage of any community programs or discounts that can help us stretch our money further. It's not perfect, but I think it's better to have something than nothing, and it's a way of teaching my kids the value of saving, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Ethan Schmehl: For us, saving has mostly been for a rainy day, though I'll admit it's been a bit of a struggle to build up anything substantial. We've had moments where we wanted to save for bigger things, like maybe a down payment on a home or even a vacation, but the reality of our financial situation has made those goals feel out of reach. Instead, we've focused on small, consistent savings—like setting aside whatever we can after paying the bills each month, even if it's just $20 or $30. It's more about having something to fall back on if something unexpected happens, like a medical bill or a car repair. I think the hardest part is that we're always trying to balance saving with the immediate needs of the family. We've had to make tough choices, like cutting back on non-essentials or relying on community support when we need it most. Still, I believe in the value of saving, even in small ways, and I hope to teach my kids that it's important to plan for the future, no matter how uncertain it may seem.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Ethan Schmehl: My occupation has been as a case manager at HopeBridge, a local nonprofit organization that provides support services to low-income families, individuals experiencing homelessness, and those in crisis situations. The most important activities and duties involve assessing clients' needs, coordinating with other agencies, and helping them access essential resources like housing, food assistance, and mental health services. I spend a lot of time meeting with clients one-on-one, listening to their stories, and working with them to create a plan that helps them stabilize their lives. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel overwhelmed by the scale of the challenges people face—but what keeps me going is seeing the progress they make. Whether it's a client who finds stable housing after months of uncertainty or someone who gets back on their feet after a difficult period, those moments remind me why I chose this path. It's not glamorous work, and the pay isn't great, but I believe in the impact we can have, even if it's just one person at a time. I think what makes this job meaningful for me is that it's not just about solving problems—it's about building relationships, offering support, and being there for people when they need it most.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Ethan Schmehl: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the caseload and any urgent situations that come up. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often stay late a few times a week to wrap up meetings or coordinate with other agencies. There are also days when I need to make home visits or attend community events, which can add a few extra hours to my schedule. It's not always a nine-to-five job, but I've come to accept that the work requires flexibility, especially when people are in crisis and need support right away. I've learned to manage my time as best as I can, but there are definitely weeks when I feel like I'm running on empty. Still, I know that the work I do matters, and that keeps me going, even when the hours are long and the stress is high.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Ethan Schmehl: No, I haven't had more than one job in recent years. I've been fully committed to my role at HopeBridge, though there were a few times early in my career when I took on part-time work at a community center to help make ends meet. That was before I got married and before we had kids, so it was more of a temporary thing. Now, with the demands of my job and being a parent, I've found that splitting my time between multiple jobs just isn't feasible. I've learned to focus on what I can do well and be present for—whether it's my work, my family, or the people I serve. It's not always easy, but I think that's the reality of the life I've chosen.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my life has changed over the past year, especially in terms of my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation. I used to think that pushing through everything on my own was the only way to be strong, but I've learned that taking care of my mental and physical health is just as important as the work I do for others. Incorporating mindfulness, journaling, and open conversations with my wife has helped me manage my stress better, even when things feel overwhelming. At the same time, dealing with the financial pressures of raising two kids while working in the nonprofit sector has been a constant challenge. I've had to be more intentional with our budget, cut back on non-essentials, and rely on community support when needed. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the small steps we've taken to stay afloat and for the people who believe in us. These experiences have taught me that resilience isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding ways to cope that work for you.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Ethan Schmehl: In total, our household made around $4,800 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at HopeBridge and Claire's part-time work at the community health center. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and a little extra for the kids' activities or unexpected expenses. I think the hardest part is knowing that even with both of us working, we're still stretching every dollar. We've had to be really careful with our budget, and I've learned to appreciate the small things—like a meal we can afford or a weekend where we don't have to worry about bills. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how we've managed to stay afloat and keep our heads above water. I know it's not the life I imagined when I was younger, but it's the life I've built with the people I love, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Ethan Schmehl: I've been at HopeBridge for about seven years now, and while the job has its challenges, the benefits have been pretty essential for us. We have health insurance, which covers both of us and the kids, and that's been a huge relief, especially with my back issues and blood pressure. We also get a certain amount of paid time off, though it's not as generous as I'd like—it's more of a basic package. I have sick days, and I've used a few of them when I was recovering from surgery or when I needed to take a break from the stress. The workplace itself is pretty supportive, especially when it comes to understanding the demands of being a parent. They allow flexible hours when needed, and I've had managers who were willing to adjust my schedule if something came up with the kids. It's not a perfect system, but I think the benefits we have are better than many in the nonprofit sector, and they've definitely helped us stay afloat during tough times.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Ethan Schmehl: My relationships at work are pretty much what you'd expect from a nonprofit environment—supportive, sometimes stressful, but ultimately built on a shared sense of purpose. I have a good relationship with my manager, Sarah. She's been with the organization for over a decade, and she's someone who truly understands the challenges of the work we do. She's not just focused on metrics or efficiency; she genuinely cares about the people we serve and the well-being of her team. I've had moments where I've felt overwhelmed, and she's always been someone I can talk to without judgment. As for my coworkers, I'd say we're a pretty tight-knit group. We've been through a lot together—late nights, tough cases, even some personal struggles. There's a real sense of camaraderie, and I think that's what keeps us going. We look out for each other, whether it's covering for someone who's sick or just offering a listening ear when things get heavy. I wouldn't say it's perfect—there are disagreements and moments of frustration, like any workplace—but overall, I feel lucky to be part of a team that values empathy, collaboration, and making a real difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Ethan Schmehl: My work schedule is pretty predictable most of the time, but there's definitely some flexibility built into it. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and finish at 5 p.m., but I often stay late a few times a week, especially when there are urgent cases or meetings that need to be handled. The nature of the work means that sometimes things come up unexpectedly—like a client in crisis or a last-minute meeting with a partner agency—and that can shift my hours a bit. On the other hand, I do have some flexibility when it comes to adjusting my schedule for family needs. For example, if one of the kids is sick or if I need to pick up a doctor's appointment, my manager is usually understanding and willing to make adjustments. That flexibility is something I really appreciate, especially with the demands of being a parent. It's not always perfect, but it helps me balance the responsibilities of work and family in a way that feels manageable.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Ethan Schmehl: Overall, I feel like we're managing, but it's a constant balancing act. There are days when I look at our budget and feel like we're just scraping by, and other days when I'm proud of how we've stretched every dollar to make sure the kids have what they need. I know we're not wealthy, and I know that financial stability is something I probably wouldn't have achieved if I had taken that corporate job after college, but I also know that the life we've built together—raising two kids, being part of a community that values service and connection—means more to me than any amount of money ever could. I'm not blind to the challenges, and I know that one missed paycheck or a sudden medical bill could throw us off track, but I also believe in the resilience of our family and the support systems we've built. I think, in the end, it's not about how much we make, but how we use what we have to make a difference—not just for ourselves, but for the people around us.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my family and I have had to adapt to the fluctuating nature of our finances and the demands of my job. It's been a year of learning to budget more carefully, anticipating seasonal changes in our expenses, and making tough choices about what we can and cannot afford. I've come to appreciate the small savings we've managed to build, even if it's not much, and I'm grateful for the support from my workplace and the community around us. It's not always easy to balance work, family, and financial stability, but I've learned that resilience isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding ways to cope that work for you.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Ethan Schmehl: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a civil engineer, and he worked full-time even after I was born. He had a graduate degree, so he was able to find stable work, which was a big help for our family. My mom, on the other hand, worked part-time as a teacher's aide, which allowed her to be more present for our family life while still contributing to our income. I remember her working late sometimes, but she always made sure to be there for me and my sister in the mornings. It wasn't always easy for them—especially with the financial challenges we faced—but they never let that stop them from giving me and my sister the best they could. I think that's why I value education and hard work so much. I saw how much my parents sacrificed to give us opportunities, and it's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Ethan Schmehl: My father worked as a civil engineer, and his most important activities involved designing and overseeing infrastructure projects—roads, bridges, and public buildings. He had a strong work ethic and was always passionate about making sure the structures he worked on were safe and functional. I remember him coming home tired but proud, especially when a project was completed successfully. He often talked about how his work helped the community, even if it wasn't always visible to everyone. My mother worked as a teacher's aide, and her most important duties involved supporting the teachers in the classroom, helping with lesson planning, and providing one-on-one assistance to students who needed extra help. She had a real gift for connecting with kids, and I think that's why she was so good at her job. Even though she worked part-time, she always made sure to be there for us, whether it was helping with homework or just being present for family dinners. I think their work shaped my values—my father's dedication to building something that lasted, and my mother's compassion for others. Those are the things I carry with me today, whether I'm working with clients or just trying to be a good father and husband.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Ethan Schmehl: My father worked for a municipal engineering firm, and my mother worked for a local public school district. My dad's job involved a lot of on-site work—surveying land, designing blueprints, and overseeing construction projects. He was often out in the field, which meant he wasn't always home when I was a kid, but he made up for it by being fully present when he was there. He had a real passion for his work, and I remember him talking about how he wanted to build things that would last for generations. My mom, on the other hand, worked directly with teachers and students. She helped with classroom management, provided extra support to kids who needed it, and even helped organize school events. She didn't make as much as my dad, but she always found ways to make ends meet, and she never let financial struggles define her work or her family. I think both of them had a strong sense of duty—my dad to the structures he built, and my mom to the kids she helped. Their work wasn't always glamorous, but it was meaningful, and I think that's why I ended up choosing a career in social work. I wanted to be someone who made a difference, just like they did, even if it wasn't always easy.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Ethan Schmehl: Looking a few years ahead, I hope that my life continues to be rooted in the values that have guided me so far—service, family, and community. I hope that my kids grow up to be compassionate, resilient, and curious about the world, just like I hope to be for them. I'd love to see us still living in this neighborhood, even if it means continuing to fight for the resources and opportunities that make it a place worth staying in. I also hope that my work at HopeBridge continues to make a meaningful impact, whether it's through helping more people find stability or advocating for better support systems in our community. I know it's not always easy, and I don't expect everything to be perfect, but I hope that we keep finding ways to grow—together, as a family, and as a part of something bigger than ourselves. I hope that in the years to come, I can look back and feel proud of the life we've built, not because it's easy, but because it's real, it's full of love, and it's made a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Ethan Schmehl: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have been there through the good times and the hard times. My family, my friends, the clients I work with, and the neighbors in this community—they're what give my life meaning. I value the sense of purpose that comes from trying to make a difference, even in small ways. I value the resilience that comes from knowing that life isn't always easy, but we keep showing up for each other. I also value the lessons I've learned along the way—about humility, about asking for help, and about finding joy in the little things. Whether it's watching my kids laugh, sharing a meal with friends, or seeing a client take a step toward stability, those moments are what I carry with me. I think, in the end, it's not about the things we have, but the connections we build and the love we give—that's what matters most.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my life has changed over the past year, especially in terms of my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation. I used to think that pushing through everything on my own was the only way to be strong, but I've learned that taking care of my mental and physical health is just as important as the work I do for others. Incorporating mindfulness, journaling, and open conversations with my wife has helped me manage my stress better, even when things feel overwhelming. At the same time, dealing with the financial pressures of raising two kids while working in the nonprofit sector has been a constant challenge. I've had to be more intentional with our budget, cut back on non-essentials, and rely on community support when needed. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the small steps we've taken to stay afloat and for the people who believe in us. These experiences have taught me that resilience isn't about being perfect—it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding ways to cope that work for you.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and connection. It's amazing how much of who I am today has been shaped by the people, choices, and challenges I've faced. From my childhood in Chicago, where my parents worked hard to give me opportunities, to the pivotal decision I made after college to pursue social work instead of a corporate job, every step has led me to where I am now—with my family, working in a field that aligns with my values, and striving to make a difference in my community. Talking about my health struggles, my financial realities, and the support I've received from my wife, my coworkers, and my neighbors has reminded me of the strength that comes from vulnerability and connection. I've learned that life isn't about perfection, but about showing up, even when it's hard, and finding meaning in the small, everyday moments. This reflection has deepened my appreciation for the life I've built—not because it's easy, but because it's real, it's full of love, and it's made a difference in the lives of others.
